Chief Complaint: OUTPATIENT CARDIOLOGIST:  [**Doctor Last Name 2563**]
   .
   PCP: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 252**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 75**]
   .
   .
   CHIEF COMPLAINT: weakness, ankle swelling
   24 Hour Events:
   HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS:69 yo m with hx of systolic [**Last Name (LF) 7132**], [**First Name3 (LF) 300**]
   15-20%, s/p CABG x2, s/p MVR and tricuspid valve annuloplasty ring and
   PAF for which he is on coumadin and ITP who presents with increased
   weakness and difficulty ambulating due to left ankle pain. He has had
   multiple admissions recently, one from [**3-12**]- [**3-15**] for heart failure
   exacerbation at which time he had been started on spironolactone 25
   daily and his lasix dose increased from 60 to 80, and then again
   [**2072-3-18**]  due to misinterpretation of med dosing instructions, he was
   taking two 5mg tabs daily instead of two (2.5mg) tabs. At time of dc
   his INR was 2.4 and he was dc'd on stable dose of 5mg coumadin. He was
   also noted to be hypovolemic and hypernatremic with Cr 2.1 from
   baseline 1.0-1.4 and his lasix and aldactone were initially stopped
   then restarted at 40 and 235 respectively on [**2154-3-25**].  Three days prior
   to this admission he had noted progressive dyspnea on exertion and
   weakness as well as ankle pain,as well as increased swelling in his
   ankles and abdomen, but what was most bothersome to him was his pain in
   his left ankle on ambulation which was limiting his mobility and so he
   presented to the ED on [**2154-3-29**] where he was noted to be in afib and
   volume overloaded on exam with BNP elevated to [**Numeric Identifier 11793**] from 7201 and INR
   elevated to 20 with no evidence bleeding and he was reversed with
   vitamin K. He was also found to be in acute on chronic renal failure
   with Cr 2.2 from baseline He had a CXR showing mild pulmonary vascular
   congestion with small bilateral pleural effusions and a retrocardiac
   opacity likely represents atelectasis, although underlying infection
   cannot be excluded. Foot x-ray was negative for fx with evaluation by
   ortho with diagnosis of cellulitis with hematoma for which he was
   started on vanc/ceftaz. EKG showed atrial fibrillation at 98 bpm with
   LVH, intraventricular conduction delay and overall no changes from
   prior.
   .
   He was diuresed with lasix IV 20 in ED and  then continued to receive
   IV boluses on [**Hospital1 2259**] and was diuresed with lasix boluses (40mg IV BID)
   then subsequently changed to lasix drip yesterday, limited by systolic
   bp's 80-90s with his baseline around 90 with I/O even unable to get
   negative. His Cr was also creeping up, from and eventually started on
   milrinone drip on the floor and subsequently transfered to the ICU for
   ionotrope assisted diuresis.
   He had been on lisinopril 5 as o/p which was titrated down over course
   of weekend and dc'd on day of ICU admission.
   His INR was 1.8 after being reversed with vit K and was started on
   heparin bridge, but on day of ICU transfer he was noteed to have nose
   bleed and INR at 2.6 so hep dc'd.
   On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep
   venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery,
   myalgias, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. he denies
   recent fevers, chills or rigors. S/he denies exertional buttock or calf
   pain. All of the other review of systems were negative.
   .
   Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain,
   paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea,  palpitations, syncope or
   presyncope.
   .
   [**2154-4-1**]: Echo
   2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM:  The left atrium is moderately dilated. No left
   atrial mass/thrombus seen (best excluded by transesophageal
   echocardiography). The right atrial pressure is indeterminate. Left
   ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity is
   moderately dilated with severe global hypokinesis. The basal inferior
   and inferolateral wall is hypokinetic but moves best, the remaining
   segments are near akinetic (LVEF <20 %). The estimated cardiac index is
   depressed (<2.0L/min/m2). No masses or thrombi are seen in the left
   ventricle. The right ventricular cavity is markedly dilated with severe
   global free wall hypokinesis. The diameters of aorta at the sinus,
   ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are
   mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic
   regurgitation is seen. A bioprosthetic mitral valve prosthesis is
   present. The mitral prosthesis appears well seated, with normal leaflet
   motion and transvalvular gradients. No mitral regurgitation is seen.
   [Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be
   significantly UNDERestimated.] The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly
   thickened. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There
   is no pericardial effusion.
   Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2152-12-26**], the
   estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is now lower.
   Biventricular cavity size is now increased with similar systolic
   function.
   CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS:
   The left ventricular ejection fraction is <40%, a threshold for which
   the patient may benefit from a beta blocker and an ACE inhibotor or
   [**Last Name (un) 239**].
   .
   Echo ([**2153-9-5**]): The left atrium is markedly dilated. The right atrium
   is moderately dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular
   hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. There is
   severe global left ventricular hypokinesis (LVEF = 15-20%). The
   estimated cardiac index is depressed (<2.0L/min/m2). The right
   ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with moderate global free wall
   hypokinesis. There is abnormal septal motion/position consistent with
   right ventricular pressure/volume overload. The aortic valve leaflets
   (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace
   aortic regurgitation is seen. A bioprosthetic mitral valve prosthesis
   is present. The mitral prosthesis appears well seated, with normal
   leaflet motion and transvalvular gradients. No mitral regurgitation is
   seen. [Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation
   may be significantly UNDERestimated.] A tricuspid valve annuloplasty
   ring is present. The tricuspid annuloplasty ring appears well seated
   and is not obstructing flow. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is
   seen. There is severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is
   no pericardial effusion.
   .
   IMPRESSION: Severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Dilated right
   ventricle with moderate systolic dysfunction and evidence of
   pressure/volume overload. Normally-functioning mitral valve
   bioprosthesis. Tricuspid valve annuloplasty ring with moderate residual
   central regurgitation. Severe pulmonary hypertension.
   Holter [**2153-8-28**]: aPBs
   CARDIAC CATH: [**2151-10-12**]:
   1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system
   demonstrated severe native 3-vessel disease. The LMCA was 90% occluded.
   The LAD was totally occluded proximally; the distal LAD filled via a
   patent LIMA graft. The LCX was totally occluded proximally; OM1 filled
   via an SVG; the sequential graft from OM1 to OM2 was occluded, but
   OM2 filled via a robust epicardial collateral. The RCA was totally
   occluded proximally; the distal vessel filled via left-to-right
   collaterals from the grafted LAD.
   2. Selective graft angiography showed a patent SVG to OM1; the jump
   segment to OM2 was occluded, but OM2 filled via an epicardial
   collateral. The SVG to RPDA was totally occulded. The LIMA to LAD was
   widely patent.
   3. Resting hemodynamics revealed markedly elevated biventricular
   filling
   pressures with moderate pulmonary hypertension and reduced cardiac
   index. There were large V-waves on the RA tracing consistent with
   severe
   tricuspid regurgitation.
   4. Aortography showed a heavily calcified ascending aorta.
   FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
   1. Three vessel coronary artery disease.
   2. Severe mitral regurgitation.
   3. Severe tricuspid regurgitation.
   4. LV systolic and diastolic dysfunction.
   Past Medical History:
   -Hypertension
   -Coronary Artery Disease, [**2128**] CABG LIMA to LAD, SVG to rPDA and SVG
   sequential graft to OM1 and OM2; [**2151**] CABG SVG to rPDA
   -Chronic systolic CHF EF 15-20%
   -Severe tricuspid regurgitation s/p Tricuspid valve annuloplasty ring
   [**2151**]
   -Severe mitral regurgitation s/p porcine MVR [**2151**]
   -Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation on coumadin, s/p cardioversion [**9-2**],
   h/o bradycardia with beta blocker
   -PAD s/p bilateral carotid endarterectomy
   -ITP
   -Pancreatic cysts (likely IPMN)
   -h/o cholestatic jaundice in [**2151**] (thought secondary to drug reaction,
   since resolved, had 2 liver biopsies)
   .
   Allergies: Ambien / Beta-Blockers (Beta-Adrenergic Blocking Agts)
   .
   MEDICATIONS:
   1. Nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet, SL PRN
   2. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet QD
   3. Atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet P.O qhs
   4. Calcium  Oral
   5. Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 400 unit daily
   6. Warfarin 5 mg Tablet daily
   7. Lasix 40 mg PO daily
   8. Aldactone 25 mg PO
   Social History:
   Divorced. Lives alone. 2 children. Tries to follow 2g Na diet
   with 50 ounce fluid restriction. Lives alone. He is retired.
   Former ETOH abuse [**2150**] and denies current ETOH use and denies
   illicit drug use.
   Family History:
   Mother with hyperlipidemia and died of coronary artery disease
   in her 60s. There is no family history of premature coronary
   artery disease or sudden death.
   Allergies:
   Ambien (Oral) (Zolpidem Tartrate)
   Confusion/Delir
   Beta-Blockers (Beta-Adrenergic Blocking Agts)
   Very sensitive
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Furosemide (Lasix) - 10 mg/hour
   Other ICU medications:
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below

   Vitals: T:  97.4 BP:103/43 HR:69  RR:16  O2 sat:96%  RA
   General: Alert, oriented, no acute distress
   HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear
   Neck: supple, JVP elevated to ear, no LAD
   Lungs: Clear to ausculatation bilaterally. No w/r/c.
   CV: Irregular rhythm. Normal rate. normal S1 + S2, loud systolic
   murmur at LLSB.
   Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present,
   no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly
   Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, 2+ peripheral edema to the knee
   bilterally. Erythema over left shin/ankle with tenderness to palpation.
   Compression stockings bilaterally.
   Labs / Radiology
        [image002.jpg]
   Assessment and Plan
   Summary: 69 yo m with hx of [**Year (2 digits) 7132**], MVR, and Tricuspid ring, PAF,
   admitted to [**Hospital1 2259**] with elevated INR and acute exacerbation of systolic
   heart failure with lasix driven diuresis limited by persistent
   hypotension, admitted to CCU for ionotrope assisted diuresis.
   .
   Assessment and Plan:
   .
   # Acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure: The patient presents
   with fluid overload, especially in the lower extremities. He has been
   compliant with his lasix and aldactone. He noticed his legs swelling,
   but he said his weight hasn't increased. He has been keeping to his
   fluid restriction. Notes that he has eaten soup with low sodium over
   the past couple of days, so salt intact can be a precipitant. Has low
   LVEF of 15-20% on last echo. On his last hospital discharge, his weight
   was 164.6 pounds. BNP elevated to [**Numeric Identifier 11793**] (last one: 7201).
   -Lasix IV PRN
   -strict I&Os, daily weight
   -dietary intact teaching
   -cannot be on beta blocker since symptomatic bradycardia
   .
   # Coagulopathy/microcytic anemia: INR supratherapeutic to 20 on
   admission, now 2.6 following reversal with vit K. Was being bridged to
   coumadin with hep GTT. However INR today 2.6. Goal reported 2.5-3.5
   although pt has bioprosthetic valve, and afib.Also has nose bleeding
   this am which has stopped. HCT 36.1 with MCV 81 on admission, 35y/d 31
   today.
   -d/c heparin GTT.
   -continue coumadin 2.5 for now.
   -holding ASA
   -[**Hospital1 **] crit checks
   -Guiac all stools
   -active type and screen
   -iron/hemolysis labs>? *****
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient presented with a
   creatinine of 2.2. His new baseline since [**3-20**] has been 2.0-2.2 from
   1.2 previously. Was on aldactone 25 and Lasix 40 mg PO at home which
   was held from [**3-20**] to [**3-25**]. Thought to be ATN in setting of lasix use
   but also had hyaline casts on UA suggesting prerenal compontent
   -check urine lytes
   -strict I&Os, avoid nephrotoxins
   -hold aldactone
   .
   # Bioprosthetic mitral valve: The patient has a bioprosthetic mitral
   valve and need anticoagulation
   -INR wnl,  Goal INR: 2.0-3
   # Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation: Patient currently in atrial
   fibrillation, unsure if playing a role in his exacerbation of heart
   failure, HR currently wnl
   -Continue to monitor on telemetry
   -continue to hold metoprolol given hypotension
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Likely due to low intravascular volume , CHF appears
   hypervolemic on exam.
   -previously in 130s, 126 on admission, now 121. Asymptomatic.
   Continue to trend.
   .
   # Hypertension: currently hyotensive.
   -holding lisinopril, metoprolol for now
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue home atorvastatin
   .
   # Diet: Low salt, cardiac heart healthy
   .
   # PIV: PICC, 20 guage.
   .
   # Code status: full code, confirmed
   .
   # Dispo: floor for now
   .
   .
   .
   [**Doctor First Name 11738**] [**Doctor Last Name 11739**]
   Internal Medicine, [**Pager number 11740**]
   ---------------------------------------------------------------------
   [**Hospital1 2259**] B Progress Note, [**4-1**]
   .
   S: Patient still very weak. Has pain in the left leg when puts weight
   on it. No nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, fevers, chills,
   headache, back ache, melena, BRBPR.
   .
   O:
   Admission Physical Exam:
   Vitals: T: 98.1, BP: 83/44 (80-95)/(46-78), HR: 83, RR: 20, O2 sat:
   100% RA
   Admission weight: 74.2 kg
   General: Alert, oriented, no acute distress
   HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear
   Neck: supple, JVP elevated to ear, no LAD
   Lungs: Clear to ausculatation bilaterally. No w/r/c.
   CV: Irregular rhythm. Normal rate. normal S1 + S2, loud systolic
   murmur at LLSB.
   Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present,
   no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly
   Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, 2+ peripheral edema to the knee
   bilterally. Brusing on left shin with tenderness to palpation. Cool
   left foot, 1+ DP/PT pulses Sensation intact. Able to wiggle toes on
   left
   .
   Assessment and Plan:
   .
   #Acute exacerbation of stystolic heart failure: admitted with evidence
   volume overload worsened in setting possible dieterary salt load, with
   pt compliant with lasix/aldactone therapy and fluid restriction. Unable
   on floor to diuresis with lasix bolus/drip given persistent
   asymptomatic hypotension.
   Continue lasix drip with goal urine output 100cc/hr, weaning as
   tolerated. If  unable to achieve, add milrinone to maintain BP while
   uptitrating diuretic. If hypotension with milrinone can start low dose
   phenylephrine. Lisinopril restarted on admission, down titrated and
   dc'd today due to hypotension.
   -continue lasix drip 5-15mg/kg/hr
   -daily weights, strict I/O goal neg 1L/day.
   -fluid restrict <1L/day
   Hold  holding BB given asymptomatic bradycardia
   -restart lisinopril if Cr/K tolerates for afterload reduction.
   -pt does not desire ICD.
   .
   # LLE cellulitis. Being followed by ortho. On ancef (started [**3-31**]) and
   elevation.
   continue ancef
   Can weight bear.
   f/u ortho recs
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient presented with a
   creatinine of 2.2, higher than his baseline of 1.2. Currently at Cr of
   2.2. Likely ATN in the setting of lasix use and/or pre-renal if low EF
   (forward flow).
   -send urine lytes
   -strict I&Os, avoid nephrotoxins
   -trend Cr
   .
   # Transaminitis on admission likely due to hepatic congestion, no RUQ
   tenderness or epigastric discomfort. Trending down from ALT/AST 80s to
   -Continue to trend LFTs
   # Hyperkalemia: Might be due to lisinopril, renal failure.
   -Continue lasix gtt
   -PM lytes
   .
   # Transaminitis: likely due to hepatic congestion, no RUQ tenderness or
   epigastric discomfort.
   -Continue to trend LFTs
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: low sodium, heart healthy diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2154-4-1**] 03:00 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2154-4-1**] 03:28 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: coumadin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Patient
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU for now.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following:

**Chief Complaint:** Weakness, ankle swelling

**History of Presenting Illness:** The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of systolic heart failure, mitral valve replacement, tricuspid valve annuloplasty, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. He was admitted with elevated INR and acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure with lasix-driven diuresis limited by persistent hypotension.

**Past Medical History:**

* Coronary artery disease
* Chronic systolic CHF with EF 15-20%
* Severe tricuspid regurgitation
* Mitral regurgitation
* Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
* ITP
* Pancreatic cysts (likely IPMN)
* Cholestatic jaundice in the past (thought secondary to drug reaction)

**Current Condition:**

* Acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure with fluid overload
* Coagulopathy/microcytic anemia with INR supratherapeutic to 20 on admission
* Acute on chronic renal failure with creatinine of 2.2
* Bioprosthetic mitral valve
* Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
* Hyponatremia
* Hypertension
* Hyperlipidemia

**Assessment and Plan:**

* Acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure: Continue lasix drip with goal urine output 100cc/hr, weaning as tolerated. If unable to achieve, add milrinone to maintain BP while uptitrating diuretic.
* Coagulopathy/microcytic anemia: Continue coumadin 2.5 mg daily.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: Send urine lytes, strict I&Os, avoid nephrotoxins, and trend Cr.
* Bioprosthetic mitral valve: Continue INR monitoring with goal INR 2.0-3.0.
* Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation: Continue to monitor on telemetry and hold metoprolol given hypotension.
* Hyponatremia: Trend Cr.
* Hypertension: Hold lisinopril and metoprolol for now.
* Hyperlipidemia: Continue home atorvastatin.
* Diet: Low salt, cardiac heart healthy.
* PIV: PICC line, 20 gauge.
* Code status: Full code.
* Disposition: ICU for now.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Worsening of systolic heart failure with fluid overload
* Coagulopathy leading to bleeding or thrombosis
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) or chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression
* Bioprosthetic valve dysfunction or thrombosis
* Atrial fibrillation with embolic risk
* Hyponatremia with potential for seizures or other neurological complications
* Hypertension with potential for cardiovascular complications
* Hyperlipidemia with potential for cardiovascular complications

**Recommendations:**

* Monitor patient's condition closely for signs of worsening heart failure, bleeding, or kidney injury.
* Adjust diuretic and vasodilator therapy as needed to manage fluid overload and blood pressure.
* Continue to monitor INR and adjust anticoagulation therapy as needed.
* Consider consultation with cardiothoracic surgery or interventional cardiology for potential interventions to improve cardiac function.
* Monitor patient's electrolyte levels and adjust therapy as needed to manage hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.
* Consider consultation with nephrology for management of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, cellulitis, acute on chronic renal failure, transaminitis, and hyperkalemia. The patient's condition has been stabilized, with improvements in creatinine levels and blood pressure. However, the patient remains at risk for potential medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Continued heart failure and decreased cardiac output due to ongoing diuretic therapy.
	* Risk of arrhythmias, particularly atrial fibrillation, due to electrolyte imbalances and cardiac medications.
2. Renal Complications:
	* Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to prolonged use of diuretics and potential nephrotoxins.
	* Worsening renal function and potential need for dialysis.
3. Infection Complications:
	* Cellulitis may progress to sepsis or spread to other areas of the body.
	* Risk of catheter-related infections due to PICC line placement.
4. Metabolic Complications:
	* Hyperkalemia may worsen due to continued use of lisinopril and potential nephrotoxins.
	* Risk of hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to insulin therapy.
5. Other Complications:
	* Risk of bleeding due to platelet count of 123 K/uL.
	* Risk of liver damage due to continued transaminitis.

Based on this information, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent or minimize potential medical complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, cellulitis, acute on chronic renal failure, transaminitis, and hyperkalemia. He has a history of severe asymptomatic bradycardia and is sensitive to beta-blockers. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 68-81 bpm, blood pressure of 91/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 95%. His laboratory results show an elevated creatinine of 1.7 mg/dL, potassium level of 4.8 mEq/L, and transaminases trending down.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening Heart Failure: The patient's heart failure is likely to worsen due to the persistence of volume overload and asymptomatic hypotension.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL suggests ongoing renal failure, which may worsen if not managed properly.
3. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level of 4.8 mEq/L is above the normal range, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications if not managed.
4. Cellulitis: The patient's cellulitis may worsen if not properly treated, leading to sepsis and other complications.
5. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to liver damage and other complications.
6. Hypotension: The patient's asymptomatic hypotension may worsen if not properly managed, leading to organ dysfunction and other complications.
7. Bradycardia: The patient's history of severe asymptomatic bradycardia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to cardiac arrest and other complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue lasix drip to manage heart failure and fluid overload.
2. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust diuretic therapy as needed.
3. Manage hyperkalemia with potassium-lowering medications and strict electrolyte monitoring.
4. Continue cellulitis treatment with antibiotics and monitor for signs of sepsis.
5. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust treatment as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust treatment as needed to prevent hypotension.
7. Monitor the patient's heart rate and adjust treatment as needed to prevent bradycardia.

The patient has a PICC line in place and is receiving prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer. He has a Code Status of Full Code.

4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium levels are elevated, and he is at risk for further electrolyte imbalances. Further evaluation and treatment may be needed to manage his electrolyte levels.
5. Transaminitis: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and he has a history of transaminitis. Further evaluation and treatment may be needed to manage his liver function.
6. Blood Pressure Management: The patient's blood pressure is being managed with IV lasix drip and phenylephrine, but further evaluation and treatment may be needed to manage his blood pressure.
7. Fluid Overload: The patient has a history of fluid overload, and further evaluation and treatment may be needed to manage his fluid status.

These are the potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided in the patient's progress note.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient is a 67-inch tall individual with a weight not specified, admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of acute on chronic systolic heart failure and cellulitis. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4C (97.5F) and 36.1C (96.9F) at different times, a heart rate of 68-81 bpm, blood pressure of 91/45 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 12-29 inspirations per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 95% on room air, and their heart rhythm is atrial fibrillation.

The patient's physical examination reveals an alert and oriented individual with no acute distress. The head, eyes, ears, nose, and throat (HEENT) examination is normal, with a supple neck and no jugular venous distension. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and the cardiovascular examination shows an irregular rhythm with a normal rate, normal S1 and S2 sounds, and a loud systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. The abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended, with present bowel sounds. The extremities are warm, well-perfused, and show 2+ pulses and 2+ peripheral edema up to the knee bilaterally, with bruising and tenderness on the left ankle.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 4.7 K/uL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 30.8%
* Platelet count (Plt): 123 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 2.0 mg/dL and 1.7 mg/dL
* Glucose: 118 mg/dL and 98 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 24.0/39.6/2.3, Ca++: 8.2 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.3 mg/dL, PO4: 3.3 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Furosemide (Lasix) 15 mg/hour
* Other ICU medications not specified
* Other medications: Ambien (Oral) (Zolpidem Tartrate), beta-blockers (Beta-Adrenergic Blocking Agts)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening heart failure with fluid overload and pulmonary edema
2. Sepsis and septic shock due to cellulitis
3. Venous thromboembolism (VTE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) given the patient's immobility and risk factors
4. Stress ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding due to increased cortisol levels and poor perfusion
5. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
6. Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to poor glucose control and medication administration
7. Electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia, given the patient's laboratory results
8. Infection and sepsis due to the patient's immunocompromised state and indwelling lines and catheters
9. Respiratory failure and need for non-invasive or invasive ventilation due to the patient's atrial fibrillation and heart failure
10. Kidney injury and acute kidney injury (AKI) due to the patient's heart failure, hypotension, and nephrotoxic medications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 67-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, chronic kidney disease, cellulitis, and hyperkalemia. He is receiving lasix drip for diuresis and has a PICC line for antibiotic administration. His vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure in the low 90s and a heart rate of 82 beats per minute. His respiratory support is minimal, with an oxygen saturation of 98%. His physical examination reveals clear lungs, a normal cardiac examination, and mild peripheral edema.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Acute Kidney Injury (AKI):** The patient's creatinine level has decreased from 2.2 to 1.6, suggesting possible recovery from AKI. However, continued monitoring is necessary to prevent further kidney damage.
2. **Volume Overload:** The patient's net negative fluid balance of 1.5 L may lead to hypotension or cardiac instability if not managed properly.
3. **Cellulitis:** The patient's left lower extremity cellulitis may progress to more severe forms of infection, such as sepsis or necrotizing fasciitis, if not properly managed with antibiotics and wound care.
4. **Hyperkalemia:** The patient's potassium level of 4.3 mmol/L is elevated and may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness if not managed with potassium-lowering medications.
5. **Cardiac Arrhythmias:** The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and bioprosthetic valve replacement may increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial flutter or ventricular tachycardia.
6. **Gastrointestinal Bleeding:** The patient's use of anticoagulation therapy and aspirin may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. **Infection:** The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of central lines and catheters may increase his risk of infection, such as catheter-related bloodstream infection or ventilator-associated pneumonia.
8. **Malnutrition:** The patient's low sodium diet and potential malnutrition may lead to decreased muscle mass and strength, increasing his risk of falls and other complications.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue lasix drip for diuresis and monitor for signs of volume overload or hypotension.
2. Monitor the patient's potassium level and adjust therapy as necessary to maintain normal potassium levels.
3. Continue antibiotics for cellulitis and monitor for signs of infection or sepsis.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary to prevent cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Consider consultation with a nutritionist to optimize the patient's nutrition and prevent malnutrition.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, acute on chronic renal failure, cellulitis, and transaminitis. He has a history of atrial fibrillation with a bioprosthetic valve and ring. The patient is currently receiving lasix drip for heart failure and fluid restriction. He has a low-sodium, heart-healthy diet and is being monitored for glycemic control.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 82 bpm, blood pressure of 98/46 mmHg, and SpO2 of 98%. His hemodynamic monitoring shows a net negative fluid balance of 1.5 L over the past 24 hours, with a urine output of 140 cc/hr. His renal function is improving, with a creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's heart failure is acute on chronic, and he is at risk of further decompensation. Close monitoring of his fluid status and cardiac function is essential.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is improving, but he is still at risk of developing acute kidney injury (AKI) due to his underlying chronic kidney disease and the use of lasix.
3. Cellulitis: The patient's cellulitis is improving, but he is at risk of developing sepsis or other complications if not properly treated.
4. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis is improving, but he is at risk of developing liver failure if not properly managed.
5. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, and he is at risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias if not properly managed.
6. Bleeding risk: The patient is taking anticoagulant therapy for atrial fibrillation, and he is at risk of bleeding complications.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections due to his compromised immune system and the use of central lines.

Recommendations:

1. Continue lasix drip for heart failure and fluid restriction.
2. Monitor the patient's fluid status and cardiac function closely.
3. Continue to trend the patient's renal function and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's cellulitis and treat any signs of sepsis or other complications.
5. Continue to trend the patient's transaminitis and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's potassium level and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust his anticoagulant therapy as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and treat any signs of infection promptly.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, cellulitis, and acute on chronic renal failure. The patient is currently receiving a furosemide drip at 15mg/hour and has a net negative fluid balance of 1.5L over the past 24 hours. His vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure in the low 90s and a heart rate of 82bpm. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with a bioprosthetic valve and is currently in sinus rhythm. His laboratory results show a creatinine level of 1.6mg/dL, which has improved from his admission level of 2.2mg/dL. His liver function tests are trending down, and his electrolyte levels are stable.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Further worsening of heart failure: The patient's fluid balance is still negative, and his blood pressure is in the low 90s, which may indicate ongoing heart failure.
2. Development of renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is still elevated, and his kidney function may continue to decline if not managed properly.
3. Progression of cellulitis: The patient has cellulitis on his left lower extremity, which may spread to other areas if not treated promptly and effectively.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient is receiving anticoagulant therapy, which may increase his risk of bleeding complications, especially in the setting of cellulitis.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's potassium level is slightly elevated, which may require close monitoring and potential adjustments to his medication regimen.
6. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver function tests are trending down, but may still require close monitoring to ensure that his liver function is not worsening.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's heart rate is stable, but may become unstable if his heart failure worsens or if he develops other cardiovascular complications.

The patient is a 56-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute on chronic systolic heart failure, cellulitis, and impaired aerobic capacity. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6C, heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 98/46 mmHg. The patient is receiving furosemide infusion and has been prescribed milrinone, but it was not started due to unknown reasons. The patient's laboratory results show improvement in liver function tests and electrolyte levels, with a stable hematocrit and platelet count.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's heart failure is acute on chronic, and there is a risk of worsening symptoms and decreased cardiac output.
2. Sepsis: The patient has cellulitis, which increases the risk of developing sepsis, especially if the infection spreads to other parts of the body.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's lung examination is clear, but there is a risk of developing respiratory failure due to underlying heart disease and potential fluid overload.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is 1.6 mg/dL, which is slightly elevated, and there is a risk of developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's sodium level is 124 mmol/L, which is slightly elevated, and there is a risk of developing electrolyte imbalance if the patient's sodium level becomes more severely elevated.
6. Infection: The patient has a PICC line and a 20-gauge line, which increases the risk of developing infections, such as central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) or peripheral catheter-associated infection (PCAI).
7. Thrombosis: The patient has a risk of developing thrombosis due to immobility and underlying cardiovascular disease.
8. Malnutrition: The patient is at risk of malnutrition due to impaired gut function and potential malabsorption of nutrients.
9. Cognitive impairment: The patient has impaired aerobic capacity, which may affect his cognitive function and increase the risk of developing delirium.
10. Pressure ulcers: The patient is at risk of developing pressure ulcers due to immobility and potential decreased blood flow to the skin.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-inch tall individual weighing 72.5 kg, admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, acute on chronic renal failure, transaminitis, and cellulitis. 

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 36.6C, heart rate 83 bpm, blood pressure 100/61 mmHg, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 100%. The patient is on a furosemide infusion at 15 mg/hour and has been on lasix/aldactone therapy and fluid restriction. 

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 4.7, hemoglobin of 10.4 g/dL, platelet count of 123 K/uL, and creatinine of 1.6 mg/dL. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) show an alanine transaminase (ALT) of 48 U/L and aspartate transaminase (AST) of 92 U/L. 

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation (AF) with a bioprosthetic valve and ring, and is currently in sinus rhythm. The patient's international normalized ratio (INR) is 2.3, and they are on a dose of Coumadin 2.5 mg daily. 

The patient has a diagnosis of acute on chronic renal failure, and their creatinine has improved from 2.2 to 1.6 mg/dL today. The patient's potassium level is 4.3 mEq/L, and they may have hyperkalemia due to lisinopril and renal failure. 

The patient is at risk for potential medical complications, including:

1. Heart failure exacerbation: The patient's systolic heart failure may worsen due to continued fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.

2. Renal failure progression: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may progress if they continue to have volume overload and electrolyte imbalances.

3. Liver dysfunction: The patient's transaminitis may worsen if they continue to have liver congestion and inflammation.

4. Cellulitis progression: The patient's cellulitis may progress if they do not receive adequate antibiotic treatment and wound care.

5. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia may worsen if they continue to have renal failure and electrolyte imbalances.

6. Bleeding complications: The patient's INR is 2.3, which may increase their risk of bleeding complications.

7. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte imbalances, including hyperkalemia, may worsen if they continue to have fluid overload and kidney dysfunction.

8. Infection: The patient may be at risk for infection due to their immunosuppressed state and the presence of central lines and other invasive devices.

9. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if they continue to have electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.

10. Respiratory complications: The patient may be at risk for respiratory complications, including pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), due to their underlying heart and lung disease.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-inch, 72.5 kg individual admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic systolic heart failure, cellulitis, and impaired aerobic capacity, endurance, gait, and transfers. They have a history of allergies to Ambien, beta-blockers, and sensitivity to certain medications. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 100/61 mmHg. They are receiving furosemide infusion and have been given trazodone for sleep. The patient's lab results show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, but elevated creatinine, glucose, and liver enzymes. They are also experiencing atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's acute-on-chronic systolic heart failure may worsen, leading to further fluid accumulation and respiratory distress.
2. Infection: The patient's cellulitis may progress, leading to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Bleeding risk: The patient's elevated international normalized ratio (INR) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT) may increase their risk of bleeding, especially with invasive procedures.
4. Renal dysfunction: The patient's elevated creatinine levels may indicate acute kidney injury, which may worsen if not managed promptly.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's elevated potassium and magnesium levels may lead to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
6. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may indicate liver damage or dysfunction, which may worsen if not managed promptly.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's atrial fibrillation and heart failure may lead to respiratory failure, especially if they develop pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
8. Thrombosis: The patient's elevated D-dimer levels may indicate a risk of thrombosis, especially in the legs and lungs.
9. Sepsis: The patient's cellulitis and elevated white blood cell count may lead to sepsis, which may worsen if not managed promptly.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's vital signs and lab results closely for any signs of worsening heart failure, infection, or bleeding.
2. Administer antibiotics and antifungals as prescribed to manage cellulitis and potential infections.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dosing of medications accordingly.
4. Consider adjusting the patient's anticoagulation therapy to minimize the risk of bleeding.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust dosing of medications accordingly.
6. Consider referring the patient to a specialist for further management of their liver dysfunction.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider intubation if necessary.
8. Consider administering thrombolytic agents to manage potential thrombosis.
9. Monitor the patient's temperature and consider administering antipyretics as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-inch tall, 72.5 kg individual with a history of atrial fibrillation, chronic systolic heart failure, and acute exacerbation of heart failure. They were admitted with evidence of volume overload, which worsened with a possible dietary salt load. The patient is currently receiving Lasix and Aldactone therapy, and fluid restriction is in place. They have a stable murmur and 1+ pitting edema. The patient's laboratory results show elevated creatinine, potassium, and transaminases. They have a low ejection fraction and are at risk for acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has increased to 2.2, which may be due to ATN or pre-renal failure. Close monitoring of creatinine levels is necessary to prevent further decline.
2. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, which may be due to Lisinopril, renal failure, or other factors. Monitoring of potassium levels and adjusting medications as necessary is crucial.
3. Transaminitis: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, which may be due to hepatic congestion or other factors. Close monitoring of liver enzymes and adjusting medications as necessary is necessary.
4. Heart Failure: The patient's heart failure is acute on chronic, and close monitoring of their cardiac status is necessary to prevent further decline.
5. Cellulitis: The patient has a left lower extremity cellulitis, which requires close monitoring and treatment with antibiotics.
6. Respiratory Complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which may increase their risk of respiratory complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
7. Blood Clots: The patient is at risk for blood clots due to their atrial fibrillation and heart failure. Close monitoring of their blood clotting status is necessary.
8. Nutritional Complications: The patient's diet is low in sodium and heart-healthy, but they may require further nutritional support to prevent malnutrition.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their various medical conditions to prevent further decline.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-inch tall, 72.5 kg individual admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, cellulitis, and acute on chronic renal failure. They have a history of atrial fibrillation, and their current vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 100/61 mmHg. They are receiving furosemide infusion and have been prescribed lasix and aldactone therapy. The patient has been experiencing cellulitis and is being treated with ancef and elevation. They have also been experiencing transaminitis, which is trending down, and hyperkalemia, which is improving.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of Heart Failure: The patient's systolic heart failure may worsen due to the discontinuation of lisinopril and the potential for diuretic resistance.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may progress to end-stage renal disease if not managed properly.
3. Cellulitis: The cellulitis may spread to other areas of the body if not treated promptly and effectively.
4. Transaminitis: The transaminitis may progress to liver failure if not managed properly.
5. Hyperkalemia: The hyperkalemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Bleeding Risk: The patient's international normalized ratio (INR) is 2.2, which may increase the risk of bleeding due to the use of coumadin.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state may increase the risk of infection, particularly in the setting of cellulitis and transaminitis.
8. Respiratory Complications: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) may exacerbate respiratory symptoms, leading to respiratory failure.
9. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and potentially life-threatening complications.
10. Malnutrition: The patient's low sodium diet may lead to malnutrition and worsen their overall health outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-inch, 72.5 kg individual with a history of atrial fibrillation, acute on chronic systolic heart failure, and cellulitis. They are currently in the ICU receiving treatment for their conditions. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9C, heart rate of 84 bpm, and blood pressure of 96/48 mmHg. They are receiving furosemide infusion and have been repleted with K+/Mg. The patient is refusing tylenol and has been changed to prn dosing.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and acute on chronic systolic heart failure put them at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart block, and cardiac arrest.
2. Renal Complications: The patient's heart failure and potential nephrotoxic medications (e.g., furosemide) may increase their risk of acute kidney injury or worsening chronic kidney disease.
3. Respiratory Complications: The patient's heart failure and potential pulmonary edema may increase their risk of respiratory failure or worsening respiratory status.
4. Infection Complications: The patient's cellulitis and potential indwelling catheters (e.g., PICC line) increase their risk of developing a central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) or other infections.
5. Metabolic Complications: The patient's heart failure and potential medications (e.g., furosemide) may increase their risk of developing electrolyte imbalances, such as hypokalemia or hyperkalemia.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's heart failure and potential medications (e.g., furosemide) may increase their risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding or other gastrointestinal complications.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's heart failure and potential medications (e.g., furosemide) may increase their risk of developing neurological complications, such as confusion or seizures.

Given the patient's complex medical conditions and treatment regimen, it is essential to closely monitor their vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and a history of mitral valve replacement and tricuspid ring. The patient is currently receiving lasix-driven diuresis, but is limited by persistent hypotension.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9C, heart rate of 84 bpm, and blood pressure of 96/48 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 100% and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine (2.0 mg/dL), potassium (4.7 mmol/L), and magnesium (1.4 mg/dL). The patient's white blood cell count is slightly elevated at 4.7 x 10^9/L. The patient's liver enzymes, including ALT and AST, are elevated.

The patient is at risk for several potential medical complications, including:

1. Heart failure exacerbation: The patient's heart failure is likely to worsen due to the ongoing diuresis and hypotension.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and further hypotension could lead to organ dysfunction.
3. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's elevated potassium and magnesium levels could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest potential kidney damage, and further deterioration could lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and liver enzymes suggest potential infection, which could worsen the patient's condition.
6. Bleeding: The patient's elevated international normalized ratio (INR) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) suggest potential bleeding risk, particularly with invasive procedures.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's atrial fibrillation and heart failure could lead to respiratory failure, particularly if the patient's oxygen saturation drops.

In light of these potential complications, I recommend continued close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status. The patient's diuresis should be continued, but with careful monitoring of blood pressure and electrolyte levels. The patient's anticoagulation therapy should be continued, and the patient should be closely monitored for signs of bleeding. The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored, and the patient should be considered for non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) or mechanical ventilation if necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, mitral valve replacement, and tricuspid ring, admitted to the hospital with an acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure. He has been transferred to the ICU for ionotrope-assisted diuresis due to persistent hypotension. The patient has been diagnosed with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, left lower extremity cellulitis, acute on chronic renal failure, and transaminitis. He is currently receiving diuretic therapy with Lasix, and his blood pressure remains stable.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of systolic heart failure: The patient's heart failure is acute and may worsen if not properly managed.
2. Left lower extremity cellulitis: The patient's cellulitis may progress and lead to further complications if not properly treated.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and if not properly managed, may lead to further kidney damage.
4. Transaminitis: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and if not properly managed, may lead to further liver damage.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen and lead to further complications if not properly managed.
6. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure remains stable, but may worsen if not properly managed.
7. Volume overload: The patient's volume overload may worsen if not properly managed.
8. Deterioration of cardiac function: The patient's cardiac function may deteriorate if not properly managed.

Recommendations:

1. Continue diuretic therapy with Lasix to manage the patient's volume overload.
2. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Continue antibiotic therapy for the left lower extremity cellulitis.
4. Monitor the patient's creatinine level and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Continue anticoagulation therapy with Coumadin to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation.
7. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Consider transferring the patient to the floor for further management.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and tricuspid ring. He has a history of systolic heart failure, mitral valve replacement, and tricuspid ring. The patient is currently receiving lasix-driven diuresis and has been transferred to the ICU for ionotrope-assisted diuresis due to persistent hypotension. He is also being treated for LLE cellulitis and has a drop in Hct overnight.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of systolic heart failure: The patient's condition can worsen if the diuresis is not effective, leading to increased fluid overload and further exacerbation of heart failure.
2. Infection: The patient's LLE cellulitis may progress and spread to other areas of the body, leading to sepsis and septic shock.
3. Anemia: The patient's drop in Hct may indicate a more severe anemia, which can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to the tissues and organs.
4. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine level has improved, but it is still elevated, and may continue to worsen if not managed properly.
5. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis may worsen and lead to liver dysfunction and failure.
6. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may continue to worsen and lead to increased risk of stroke and other cardiovascular complications.
7. Bleeding risk: The patient's Coumadin therapy may increase his risk of bleeding, especially with the presence of anemia and liver dysfunction.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's poor nutritional status may worsen and lead to decreased immune function and increased risk of infections.
9. Glycemic control: The patient's glucose levels may fluctuate and lead to hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia, which can worsen his condition.
10. VAP: The patient's risk of VAP may increase due to his presence in the ICU and the use of invasive lines and devices.

He is currently experiencing an acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure with lasix-driven diuresis limited by persistent hypotension.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9C (98.4F)
* Heart rate: 84 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 96/48 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Creatinine: 2.0 mg/dL (improved from 2.2 mg/dL)
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 27 mg/dL
* Potassium: 4.3 mEq/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 4.7 K/uL
* Platelet count: 123 K/uL

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the trend suggests a possible decline in renal function.
2. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, which may be due to lisinopril, renal failure, or other factors.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and his oxygen saturation is normal, suggesting possible respiratory compromise.
4. Cardiac arrhythmia: The patient is experiencing atrial fibrillation, which may be a sign of underlying cardiac disease.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, suggesting possible liver dysfunction or injury.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued lasix drip to promote diuresis
2. Fluid restriction to <2L/day
3. Hold lisinopril due to asymptomatic bradycardia
4. Continue antibiotics for cellulitis
5. Monitor creatinine and potassium levels
6. Trend liver function tests (LFTs)
7. Restart Coumadin therapy to achieve an INR of 2.3
8. Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and cardiac arrhythmia

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health status:

The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with an acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and chronic kidney disease. He has a history of mitral valve replacement and tricuspid ring placement. He was transferred to the ICU for ionotrope-assisted diuresis due to persistent hypotension despite lasix-driven diuresis.

Current vital signs:

* Temperature: 36.9C (98.4F)
* Heart rate: 84 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 96/48 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 100%
* Weight: 72.5 kg (admission weight: 77.3 kg)

Laboratory results:

* Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 30.8%
* Platelet count: 123 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 27 mEq/L
* Sodium: 137 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.0 mEq/L
* Glucose: 118 mg/dL
* INR: 2.6
* Partial thromboplastin time: 39.0 seconds
* Activated partial thromboplastin time: 26.4 seconds
* Alanine aminotransferase: 48 U/L
* Aspartate aminotransferase: 92 U/L
* Alkaline phosphatase: 97 U/L
* Total bilirubin: 1.5 mg/dL
* Differential count: Neutrophils 74.9%, lymphocytes 13.5%, monocytes 9.0%, eosinophils 2.2%

The patient has been diagnosed with acute exacerbation of systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and cellulitis in the left lower extremity. He is receiving lasix-driven diuresis and has been transferred to the ICU for ionotrope-assisted diuresis due to persistent hypotension.

Potential medical complications:

1. Worsening of systolic heart failure: The patient's heart failure symptoms may worsen due to the acute exacerbation, leading to further fluid accumulation and decreased cardiac output.
2. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen due to the acute exacerbation, leading to further increases in creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels.
3. Cellulitis progression: The patient's cellulitis in the left lower extremity may progress, leading to increased pain, swelling, and potential sepsis.
4. Bleeding risk: The patient's anticoagulation therapy with Coumadin may increase his bleeding risk, particularly with the presence of atrial fibrillation and chronic kidney disease.
5. Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's transaminitis may worsen, leading to further liver dysfunction and potential complications.

The patient's plan of care includes continued lasix-driven diuresis, close monitoring of fluid status and daily weights, holding lisinopril, and continuing fluid restriction. He is also receiving antibiotic therapy for the cellulitis and anticoagulation therapy for atrial fibrillation.
